title: Thompsons of Prudhoe breaks through £2m profit mark during strong year
text:

Construction specialist Thompsons of Prudhoe enjoyed a strong year after profits at the earthworks and quarry company broke through the £2m mark. 
The family business started life in 1948 as a small husband-and-wife partnership but has now grown into a group of companies employing 260 people. 
Latest accounts for Thompsons of Prudhoe Holding Ltd, for the year ended March 31 2016, show the profit for the financial year grew by 22% to reach £2.02m on sales of £29.7m, which had increased by 6.7%. 
John Thompson, director at the company, said in the financial statement accompanying the accounts: “The directors have considered the performance of the business during the financial year and are content with the continued progress that has been achieved. 
“The cash position of the group is managed by a bank overdraft facility provided to the group. At the year end the cash position of the group was £1.8m. 
“During the year a bank loan of £1.05m was provided to assist with the acquisition of farm land, part of which is currently operated by the group an inert landfill site and quarry.” 
The five-year bank loan was taken out to purchase the Merryshields farm in Stockfield. The facility will see the firm repay £7,124 per month at a total cost of nearly £430,000. 
At the end of the year the company’s loan account had a balance of £1,012,500. Read More Spanish City Dome contractors call in robots as regeneration work progresses 
Thompsons of Prudhoe also grew its headcount last year after hiring an extra eight people as drivers and labourers, taking the workforce up to 260 people. 
At the period end, Thompsons had net assets of £12.8m, compared with £11.1m in 2015. Read More Housebuilder Barratt Developments slows land spending in the wake of Brexit vote 
In total, it paid out a dividend of £150,000, which was the same as during the previous year. 
Thompsons’ biggest increase in turnover came from its contract work, which brought in an additional £1.02m last year and generated a total of £14.2m. 
Income from haulage stood at £7.8m while plant hire brought in £2.9m, an additional £500,000 compared with 2015. 
Tipping and concrete sales fell during the year, generating revenues of £1.4m and £528,000 respectively. Like us on Facebook
